sn47.7:1.1: “Mendicants, in the Himalayas there are regions that are rugged and impassable. In some such regions, neither monkeys nor humans can go,
sn47.7:1.2: while in others, monkeys can go but not humans.
sn47.7:1.3: There are also level, pleasant places where both monkeys and humans can go.
sn47.7:1.4: There hunters lay snares of tar on the monkey trails to catch the monkeys.
sn47.7:2.1: The monkeys who are not foolhardy and reckless see the tar and avoid it from afar.
sn47.7:2.2: But a foolish and reckless monkey goes up to the tar and grabs it with a hand.
sn47.7:2.4: Thinking to free his hand, he grabs it with his other hand.
sn47.7:2.6: Thinking to free both hands, he grabs it with a foot.
sn47.7:2.8: Thinking to free both hands and foot, he grabs it with his other foot.
sn47.7:2.10: Thinking to free both hands and feet, he grabs it with his snout.
sn47.7:2.12: And so the monkey, trapped at five points, just lies there screeching. He’d meet with tragedy and disaster, and the hunter can do what he wants with him.
sn47.7:2.13: The hunter spears him, pries him off that tarred block of wood, and goes wherever he wants.
sn47.7:2.14: That’s what happens when you roam out of your territory into the domain of others.
sn47.7:3.1: So, mendicants, don’t roam out of your own territory into the domain of others.
sn47.7:3.2: If you roam out of your own territory into the domain of others, Māra will catch you and get hold of you.
sn47.7:3.3: And what is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others?
sn47.7:3.5: It’s the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
sn47.7:3.7: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
sn47.7:3.11: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
sn47.7:3.12: This is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others.
sn47.7:4.1: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.
sn47.7:4.2: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t catch you or get hold of you.
sn47.7:4.3: And what is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers?
sn47.7:4.5: It’s the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.7:4.7: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.7:4.8: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.7:4.10: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.7:4.11: This is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers.”
